title: new decade improve politics
story: But let’s be frank. Things can only improve on the last four years of anger, ision and political paralysis.A period which should have been pivotal to our country saw it barely governed at all. That all changed at pm on December .Boris Johnson’s thumping election win gives us the greatest opportunity for radical renewal since at least .That means finally achieving Brexit  days from now and then, we hope, rapidly ­striking trade deals with Brussels and the world’s greatest economies.It means a dramatic, imaginative ­Budget to turbo-charge both those “left-behind” regions which voted Tory for the first time and the wider economy.We share too the  vision of our readers: For huge NHS investment to continue and a long-term social care solution be put in place.That tax breaks and rate cuts must renew our dilapidated High Streets and help small firms thrive and create jobs.That rough sleeping must be slashed, even ended. That wages must be driven up and food banks rendered redundant.That the Tories must continue striving for a cleaner environment without ­caving in to economy-wrecking panic.And we of course share the desire for a kinder, more united country — echoed by the open letter from faith, ­culture, sport and business leaders.The Sun is optimistic about that too.In fact we do not agree we have suffered a “decade of ision”. Yes, it was tough financially. But we were far from ided at, say, the  Olympics.The anger in our Parliament, offices, factories and homes was caused by Brexit, specically by some Remainers’ refusal to accept defeat, and by a Labour Party engulfed by the hostile hard-left.The Brexit heat is fast dissipating now. Boris’s triumph saw to that. Many Remainers are making their peace with it . . . and even seeing its opportunities.Which leaves but one obstacle to the national healing.No one has done more to ide us than Jeremy Corbyn, his thuggish, often anti-Semitic followers and his obnoxious media apologists.Their relentless hatred and dishonest demonisation of opponents toxied both political discourse and Labour’s election fortunes.Yet none of the contenders to replace Corbyn grasps this reality: They can remain a Twitter-obsessed, Tory-hating clique of middle-class Marxist posers calling each other “comrade” but disconnected from working people.Or be viable, mainstream contenders for Government. But not both.Will they make the right choice  It’s January , , and we live in hope.We are far more sure that Britain, fully independent for the first time in  years, will enjoy a golden decade in the ’s.Happy New Year to you all! Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: greta thunberg shift opinions
story: Thanks to the -year-old Swedish climate change campaigner many more of us are eco-warriors these days. Whichever box we ticked in the election, millions of us vote green with our lestyles.A recent survey of Sun readers showed  per cent recognise climate change is real and that  per cent of us worry more about our environmental impact now than they did five years ago.And  per cent of Sun readers want to make their habits greener still.Some of them make their voices heard.Retired receptionist Eileen Webster, , says “climate change is the big issue facing the next generation”, while Anna Lubecka, , demands new PM Boris Johnson, “start making good plans for climate change”.Attitudes to environmentalism have shted so much that being green is now no longer the preserve of lentil-munching hippies and Swampy, it is totally mainstream.No trendy bar would now dare put plastic straws in their cocktails.We’ve all got used to carrying Love Island-style water bottles and happily adopted reusable coffee cups. This year they pulled off a plastic-free Glastonbury, despite a few hiccups.We’ve long stopped grumbling about taking our own bags to the supermarket and got used to stuffing our pockets with them when we leave the house.So now in England, the average person uses less than a tenth of the number of single-use plastic bags than we did five years ago. Only around ten a year, compared to  in .As electric cars have improved, we’ve all been seduced — and not just by Tesla’s new “bulletproof” Cybertruck. Overall, demand for electric cars has jumped, with the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders finding that this November alone electric car sales leaped by . per cent, with more than three times as many new battery-electric vehicles registered as in the same month in .Nowhere  is it clearer that green has become the new black than in fashion, where criticism of fast fashion has led to trends for vintage, second hand and renting rather than buying.On the high street, companies such as HM have launched their “conscious collection” , fashion bible Vogue has championed sustainable designs, while French President Emmanuel Macron’s “fashion pact” — presented at the G summit and intended to make the industry more sustainable — has been signed by more than  brands, including Nike, Zara and Gap.All these changes prove how far we have come and the impact Greta has had.Hearing her, strong and calm, on Radio ’s Today programme this week, what struck me is that now another change is needed.This time a sht not in our actions, but in how we approach the environmental debate.It’s not beliefs but attitudes that need to change. Until now, environmental issues have been too isive.Butwe want real change we’ve got to move beyond blame.It puts people off environmental issues when campaigners hector and shame them.When wealthy celebrities such as Sir David Attenborough criticise normal people for taking holidays with cheap flights, or actress Emma Thompson jets back from America to harass normal people driving to work.In the same way Extinction Rebellion threatens to lose potential supporters when it starts fights with commuters trying to board their morning train or cause mayhem in central London.The real danger is that by being so aggressive, these green campaigners risk putting people off.Greta seems to know this. She is much calmer than she used to be when speaking in public.Rather than getting angry or emotional, instead she has stressed the importance of just, “listening to the scientists”.As usual, we could learn from her.The reality is most people want to be green.We are all concerned about global warming, pollution in the seas and the kind of planet we are creating for our grandkids. But you can’t shame people into doing something.Diesel drivers — especially White Van Man — shouldn’t be harassed just for getting to work. I’m sure they would buy more environmentally friendly vehiclesthey could afford to.Likewise, no one should be shamed for taking a flight — who knows what other measures they might be taking, such as living in a carbon neutral home What the planet needs least is more fighting. Instead we need grown-up debate.The answer to the climate crisis isn’t to criticise each other — it’s to work together to make real change. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: hugs clean air holidays gadgets trends 2020
story: The -year-old predicted the clean eating craze, the rise of the snowflake generation and metrosexual men and she was one of the first to warn of the  financial crash.Today we hear what New Yorker Marian – whose Annual Trends report is a bible for companies wanting to know the next big thing – is predicting for , which she believes will be the Year of the Hug.It has never been easier to reach out to friends and colleagues anywhere in the world.But the more digitally connected we all become, the more we risk becoming disconnected emotionally and physically.We each live in our own inidualised, personally curated bubble — and we are feeling the impact.At our core, humans are social animals. We need contact — and not just emotional — but physical.There’s even a psychological term for it, skin hunger.People are responding to this tech-driven disconnect by seeking out physical contact in any way they can.The most obvious example is the rise of hugging.There’s a lot more hugging as a greeting between men than there used to be, even between sporting opponents.And what on earth happened to the stand-offish Brits  Great British Bake Off contestants spend nearly as much time holding hands and wrapping their arms around each other as they do baking.We have become so hungry for touch that we don’t even need a human partner.The odds are that someone you know will have received a weighted blanket for Christmas.It is essentially a duvet cover filled with plastic or glass pellets or beads.Manufacturers say the even pressure they exert on your body promotes the release of well-being chemical serotonin and sleep hormone melatonin, while reducing stress-related hormone cortisol.In plain language we’re talking about feeling the comfort and security of being cradled, evenit’s by a blanket rather than in the arms of a loved one.For those who want to take the experience of being hugged to a whole new level, Otonamaki, the Japanese practice of adult swaddling, will become popular in .After getting into a foetal position, the client is bound tightly in sheets, then gently rocked for  minutes.I ran across a tweet not long ago that read: “My phone just said, ‘Welcome home’, and I instinctively replied, ‘I love you’. Then I realised I meant it.”We may be interacting with our fellow humans less often, but we’re more than making up for it with digital interactions, even to the point of developing feelings for these devices.As our devices get smarter and master the intricacies of natural language processing, we will increasingly see them as confidants, friends and even romantic partners.Already people are interacting with chatbots instead of flesh-and-blood therapists.And we’re seeing all sorts of digital apps promising to improve our mental health, from Moodfit and MoodMission to Happy.As developers figure out how to make our smart devices ever more personable, it doesn’t take a soothsayer to recognise that a global population increasingly suffering from loneliness and disconnectedness will find solutions of a sort in these gadgets.The desire for clean air in cities will not only lead to pricier houses on less polluted streets but tourists will give up city breaks for holidays in the country, where the air is good.As living in places with clean air becomes a luxury with a high price tag, expect new takes on face masks to become a must-have item for people in cities and a race towards rural living.Expect an explosion of products, from vegan leather to plant-based burgers and articial wood.If you buy a vegan burger and cook it at home, you have consumed a burger made with eight times less water and CO than a conventional beef burger.These sorts of products may be described as “fake” but the feelings people get of having made an ethically better choice are very real.Uncertainty begets fear, so look out for a rise in preppers — survivalists preparing for Armageddon.In the US, prepping is mainstream enough for Costco to sell a £, one-year stockpile of survival food for four.Survivalists are at the extreme end of the bunker trend.More mainstream are the millions who aren’t worried enough to go all-out prepper but still view the outside world as a threat.Driven by concerns about personal security and terrorism, CCTV covering public and commercial spaces is becoming a global norm.London is sixth in the world for TV surveillance, the only non-Chinese city in the top eight.And sales of home video surveillance on smartphones, courtesy of Google Nest, Ring and Wyze Cam, are booming.The global market is expected to rise from £billion to £billion by .Expect the self-tracking trend to run and run.For more and more people, there’s something irresistible about gadgets that put statistics to common everyday activities.For things that can’t yet be tracked automatically, they can input data manually — MyMoodTracker for emotions, MyNetDiary for nutrition and PoopLog for toilet visits.Google announced it intended to buy Fitbit for nearly £billion, prompting some to say they will ditch their device out of concern that Google will sell their health data to insurance companies.But rather than wait to buy third-party data, insurance companies are already getting into the game.: Single, professional women will become the new free-spending yuppies.: Publishes a study of the soft modern male, who she described as “metrosexual man”.: Predicts “sleep is the new sex” and “clean eating”. Forecasts the sub-prime crisis that led to the  financial crash.: Identies a new “snowflake” mindset where “everybody wants to save the Earth but no one wants to help Mum with the dishes”.: Identies Daddy bloggers as more fathers bring up kids.: Forecasts the rise of “truthiness” – where facts seem to matter little.: Predicts rise of gender-neutral society. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: cats seized micro chipped plans
story: The Government is consulting on making it compulsory for all Brits to get their felines chipped.It is already illegal for dog owners to not microchip their pets, and those who flout the law can be prosecuted and handed £ fines.One proposal being considered is handing councils the power to seize the cats and get them microchipped.The pets would then be given back to their owners who would be billed for the ID tag, typically around £.But the owner could face a finethey refused to pay the bill.The consultation on the proposed shake-up closes on January .Zac Goldsmith, Animal Welfare Minister, said: “Microchips are often the only hope of reuniting lost pets with their owners so it truly is the best New Year’s resolution you could make to protect your furry friend in .“I urge cat owners to microchip their cat and for dog-owners to make sure the details on the chip are up to date.”Jacqui Cuff, from the charity Cats Protection, said: “It is so important that cat owners microchip their pet cats as it is a safe and permanent form of identication.“Cats love to explore, and are also great escape artists, so microchipping is important for cats, even those that live indoors.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brit jihadis human rights laws return
story: Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab announced six weeks ago that infants abandoned by their ISIS fighter parents would be brought back to the UK.The Sun can reveal that government lawyers privately flagged up the risk that the move could trigger a slew of fresh claims under human rights laws.The jihadis could exploit their children’s mercy lts out of the war zone by claiming their right to family reunion to successfully overturn any ban on their .But the decision was taken by Mr Raab despite the legal warnings as well as fierce opposition from the Home Secretary, The Sun has also learned.Priti Patel argued against the rescues because of the danger their parents could cause - and was backed by Chancellor Sajid Javid and Defence Secretary Ben Wallace - but she was overruled.In addition, The Sun can also reveal that the Foreign Office and Crown Prosecution Service is looking afresh at bringing back as many as  captured British jihadis to stand trial.It is estimated that prosecutions could be brought against up to a third of the roughly  fighters locked up in camps in Kurdistan, who were taken prisoner when Islamic State was defeated.A fresh review of their status has been launched under heavy pressure from the US, who want the UK government to start taking action over the detainees now that the election is over.So far, only three children have been brought back, but as many as  more could follow.Announcing the mission in November, Mr Raab said only orphans and unaccompanied minors would be brought back to Britain as he dubbed it “the right thing to do”.He added: “These innocent children should never have been subjected to the horrors of war”.Responding to the revelations, Commons Foreign Affairs committee chairman Tom Tugendhat repeated his call for legal reforms as the current law is not up to scratch.Mr Tugendhat said: “They are British, they were radicalised here, they are our problem, but we must look very hard at bringing in legislation to toughen up the law first.“Courts must be able to convict people who have betrayed the country and then lock them up for a long time. title: ayia napa teen friend stitch up confession
story: A -year-old psychology graduate, who was with the teenager in Ayia Napa on the night of the attack, said an investigating officer re-wrote her witness statement to make it look like the pair had been drinking heavily earlier.She said: “When I saw my statement in court I couldn’t believe it. No way was it what I had written.”And the -year-old teen’s lawyer told The Sun a close examination of the language used in her statement retracting her rape allegation suggested it was not in her words.Forensic linguistic specialist Dr Andrea Nini said: “The linguistic evidence supports the hypothesis that all or some parts of the statement were not composed by the girl.“They were from a non-native English speaker. The combination of words is not what an educated English speaker would say or write.“What it appears to be is words dictated to her by someone  who didn’t speak English as their first language.” The confession reads:“The report I did on the th of July  that I was raped at Ayia Napa was not the truth. The truth is that I wasnt raped and everything that happened in that appartment was with my consent.“The reason I made the statement with the fake report is because I did not know they were recording  humiliating me that night I discovered them recording me doing sexual intercourse and I felt embarrassed so I want to appologise, say I made a mistake.”Dr Nini said: “It is very unlikely a native English speaker would write ‘report I did’ — it would be ‘the report I made.’“Also an English speaker is more likely to say ‘not true’ rather than ‘not the truth’.“The statement also contains the word apartment which is misspelt with an extra p and is more American than English. ‘Discovered them’ is also not a native English speaker’s phrase.“It’s more consistent with a person who has English as a second language.“Perhaps the most telling is the use of the phrase ‘doing sexual intercourse’ — a native English speaker would say ‘having sexual intercourse’.”The -year-old’s conviction on Monday rests on the validity of the retraction statement, which she is said to have written and signed ten days after the rape.But Dr Nini’s analysis bolsters the well-educated teenager’s claim that the many grammatical errors and spelling mistakes prove it was not written by her.Her lawyer Michael Polak said the statement was written in “Greeklish”.And he insists it was given under duress after almost eight hours of hostile questioning and with no lawyer or translator present — a breach of her human rights.The teenager’s friend, who comforted her as she sobbed and told of the hotel room rape by  Israelis, today insisted the Cypriot police never had any intention of taking them seriously.She added: “It was a stitch-up from the beginning. It felt asthey had made their minds up without even bothering to listen to us.We weren’t taken at all seriously and it felt aswe were being kept in the dark the whole time.”She told of her shock at the way in which her witness statement was taken by an investigating officer.The -year-old, who had been out for a meal with the teenager earlier, added: “There was just me and him in the room and he kept saying to me ‘So you were both drinking a bit that night ’“He was implying that we were drunk and I said that wasn’t the case. He was trying to suggest that it was all our fault because we were drunk. But we weren’t. He was writing my statement as he wanted to interpret it.”Police initially arrested  Israeli men aged between  and  in connection with the attack.But all were later released without charge and allowed home.Police say the teenager invented the rape claim after discovering film of her having consensual sex with one of the Israelis had been posted online.The teenager had started seeing the Israeli a few days earlier and had gone to a hotel room with him after having a meal with her friend.During her trial she told the court they had sex but she asked him to stop when he became violent.A HUMAN rights lawyer has slammed the conviction and said the idea the teen willingly took part in an orgy is a “ridiculous porn fantasy”.Harriet Wistrich, of the Centre for Women’s Justice, said: “I’ve never met a woman who’d consent to .I believe she had sex with one then was treated appallingly by his friends.As I understand there is video evidence of her asking the men to leave the room then they posted what they filmed online, which is particularly offensive.There appears to be a lot of material available.“She confessed under duress. To me the conviction is unsafe.“It’s also tortuous for her having the judge drag it out for so long. title: australia is gods laboratory and people were not actually meant to live there
story: He created it as a continent far, far away where he could house all his experiments that had gone wrong.It was his under-the-stairs cupboard for stuff he wanted to forget about.Like, for instance, the saltwater crocodile. He designed it, built it then realised it was far too savage and bitey to live in, say, Milton Keynes.Or the poisonous redback spider which likes to hide under lavatory seats so it can bite a man’s penis when he sits down to do his number twos. No way could God have that living in Europe or the US.He also made a lot of snakes. Some are very pretty and some are very impressive.But occasionally it all went wrong and he ended up with something that could kill a fully-grown man with one small bite. And again, these could not live in populated areas.He needed a home for all these things, so he made Australia.And to make sure people didn’t go there, he put a huge coral reef on the approaches and filled the interior with a sea of sand that goes on for ever.He even used this remote outpost to house some of his more ridiculous ideas. Stuff he came up with when he was drunk.Like those birds that can’t fly and that otter with a beak.Then you have the kangaroo, which gets about by bouncing, and the koala, which is permanently stoned and catches chlamydiaanyone ever picks it up.For millions of years, this big, sandy cupboard under the stairs went unnoticed.But then along came Captain Cook and now the world knows all about Oz and its stupid, dangerous creatures.Plainly, God is embarrassed. Because he’s decided to set fire to it.It’s been argued the fires raging across the country were caused by global warming or out-of-control barbies.But when you look at the footage, you know something biblical is going on.Those things are huge.Skies have been turned red by the flames. Choking smoke is blanketing millions of acres.Thousands of homes have been obliterated. And people are dying.This has happened before in recent years and there’s no doubt it will happen again.Which means people must accept that Australia isn’t meant for human habitation.Soyou’re reading this down there, please come home.You’ll like it. It never stops raining. And we are better at sport.DURING World War Two, General de Gaulle used London as a base and to say a belated thank you, current president Emmanuel Macron is thinking of giving the city France’s highest award for honour.Needless to say, lots of people are now jumping up and down in Paris saying the Legion d’Honneur cannot possibly be given to London as England and France are “hereditary enemies”.No we aren’t. Germany is our hereditary enemy and not just on the football pitch.France, meanwhile, is just some place we visit to buy cheese and wine.We have no idea what it’s like to fight France because it always surrenders before the battle’s got going.ALL of us begin a new decade with hope in our hearts that it’ll be better than the past one.Not me. This is thanks to two things.Firstly, there’s Libya. Since they shoved a scaffolding pole up Colonel Gaddafi’s bottom, it has been a lawless haven for terrorists and lunatics.Today it’s run by factions of the Judean People’s Front and the Popular Front For Judea, with one backed by Turkey and Qatar and the other backed by the United Arab Emirates and Egypt.There’s going to be a bloodbath. And this is a country less than  miles from mainland Europe.Which means we are going to have to get involved. Becausewe don’t, Russia will.That’s one reason, then, that I fear for the coming decade.The other is that at some point in the next ten years, statistically speaking, I am likely to die.TWENTY years ago, Britain created the perfect argument for not allowing anything to be nationalised or run by the Government.It was called The Dome.Created to mark the end of a millennium, it cost £million and was filled by right-on frizzy haired vegans with things no one wanted to see.There was a plastic human you could walk through, a multi-faith zone and lots of global warming malarkey.Unsurprisingly, it was a spectacular flop.So after a year, it was given away to a property company which turned it into the O, a music venue that now rakes in £million a year. Led Zeppelin had their reunion there.As I’ve always said, governments should put up park benches and run the nuclear submarines.And that’s it. Everything  should be run by the private sector.AS we all trudge back to work, with the fog making our hair frizzy and the puddles reminding us we need some new shoes, we will develop a teeth-rattling hatred for all those celebrities on Instagram who are frolicking in the Caribbean or sipping green juices on a beach in the Males.Amanda Holden. Pippa Middleton. Myleene Klass. Grrrr.Except,you think about it, you and I don’t have to find someone to put sun cream on our back five times a day.We aren’t being eaten alive by mosquitoes. And while a wet pavement isn’t very romantic, it’s better than hopping about, yelping, on a superheated white beach.Also, we will not have dicky tummies from the weird food, bad heads from the cocktails, puffy eyes from the jet lag and the constant worry we’ve been papped while bending over.And what’s more, we didn’t have to spend half an hour at an airport waiting for someone in a high-visibility jacket to take an X-ray photograph of our genitals.TECHNICALLY speaking, the fabulous goal scored by Wolves against Liverpool last weekend was not a goal at all.Because careful examination of the footage showed one of the players involved in the build-up was offside by .mm.It may have been three in the morning. The road may have been empty and the skies clear. And there’s no way you should have to waste a day on a speed awareness course as a result.But technology means we live in a time when there is no grey area. Pity.Many of the kids were explaining how they’d given up meat to save the planet and that Greta Thunberg may be Mrs Jesus.But then, instead of actually going walking, they stayed in the car, running its V diesel engine to keep warm.I WAS asked the other dayI’d be starting the year by doing Veganuary.FINALLY, may I wish everyone a very happy New Year.And extend a big thank you to Jeremy Corbyn and Diane Abbott for making such a thing likely.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: planes fly in v shape flocks like migrating birds
story: European manufacturer Airbus says flight technology is now mature enough to use a V-shaped formation which allows aircraft to ride on the coattails of each other.The Airbus plan called Fellofly, is the latest attempt for flight engineers to mimic the flight of birds.Within six months two A planes are set to make a long-haul formation flight to prove the so-called wake energy retrieval is safe and reliable.Dr Sandra Bour Schaeffer, chief executive of Airbus UpNext said: Weve known about the efficiency of migrating birds for a long time.The air is smooth and easy to ride and does not impact the comfort of passengers.There is huge potential in it.Formation flying will depend on the precise co-ordination of flight paths and use satellite positioning to ensure planes are suitably separated.There is no theoretical limit to the number of planes taking part but traffic will have to be managed by controllers.The tactic is often seen in cycling where racers draft behind leaders of the race, following in their slipstream.Safety is our top priority, said fellofly demonstrator Nick Macdonald.Were working to develop the s necessary to assist pilots to safely stay in position behind the leader during a long-haul flight.In early , an airline will pair two jets, with the second flying nearly two miles from the first, on a transatlantic passenger route.Within five years airlines will be encouraged to use the formation in a bid to save up to  per cent of fuel, lower costs as well as carbon emissions.For every tonne of fuel saved, three tonnes less carbon dioxide will be left in the planes trail.The new technology comes amid growing pressures around the world to cut carbon emissions.Teenage climate activist Greta Thunberg famously sailed to and from the US to avoid taking a flight.She has popularised the Swedish term flygskam, meaning flight shame, to discourage others from flying due to its environmental impact.British Airways recently announced plans to become the first UK airline to offset all carbon emissions on flights within the UK.The airlines parent company, International Airlines Group has committed to achieving net zero carbon emissions by title: labour box ticking web of wokery
story: Her cabinet — the perfect balance of men and women, Leavers and Remainers, Oxford graduates and bus drivers’ sons — made politically correct commentators wild with delight.So delighted were they, in fact, they failed to point out a minor drawback to the photogenic new line-up: The PM’s choices were mainly dim, careerist MPs who she picked purely because they ticked the right boxes.The former PM paid a high price for a few days of fawning headlines.She and her useless coterie presided over three years of ision and indecision, only to be unceremoniously dispatched by Boris Johnson and his band of Vote Leavers last summer.But the Labour party hasn’t learned from her mistakes.THERE’S something off about Jess Phillips. If she’s really troubled about racism in the Labour Party, why did she spend the past three years campaigning to get anti-Semitic Jeremy Corbyn into Number  Andshe’s a serious contender for the leadership, why does she spend half her time doing interviews about herself for glossy magazines Yes, personal brand is important. Butthe country is really in the state Jess claims, shouldn’t she be busy fixing it The Labour leadership contender is determined to paint herself as “likeable” and “relatable” but, right now, she’s coming across as a vacuous narcissist. And a slippery one at that.The race to succeed Jeremy Corbyn has so far involved the candidates hamming up their northern accents, trying to out-working class each other, or desperately bigging up their woke credentials to the Press.No one has yet adopted a whippet or done a Layla Moran, the Liberal Democrat MP and potential leadership hopeful who this week described herself out as “pansexual” — attracted to people regardless of sex — but it won’t be long now.For the casual bystander, it all makes for a good laugh. Emily Thornberry’s hysterical claim that her family was once so poor they had to put down a cat sounded so ridiculous in her cut-glass accent, it distracted commentators fromAngela Rayner’s far more legitimate tales of hardship — much to the comical irritation of the latter.For anyone serious about rebuilding the opposition, though, this farcical leadership race is no joke.While Labour contorts itself into a web of wokeness, the Conservatives are quietly cementing their new blue wall in the North.Why  Because outside leftie London and a few university towns, no one cares about tick-box ersity or even the le stories of politicians.Yes, having a “powerful backstory” is usefulyou want to make self-indulgent MPs weepy in the Commons, but it won’t persuade voters that you’re capable of getting things done.And as Boris Johnson proved so decisively last month, getting things done is what counts.The Eton and Oxford-educated Prime Minister looks and sounds nothing like most of the voters in Bishop Auckland or Redcar, but he persuaded them that he was serious about pulling Britain out of a rut.That, it turned out, was enough for an -seat majority.DOMINIC CUMMINGS is spot on: What this country needs is some more nerds.Stuffing the Civil Service full of people who meet gender and ersity quotas is all very well, butyou want employees who bring a fresh perspective, you need recruits who actually think dferently.A tech-obsessed -year-old who skipped university to pursue a career in coding could teach Whitehall’s swarms of humanities graduates a thing or two. And anyone prepared to give up a social le to work for the Government would likely do a far better job than the current civil servants who knock off at pm on a Friday.Bring on the geeks.The Opposition should now take a leaf out of his book.The last election was calamitous, yes, but with  per cent of the vote, Labour is still the second-largest party in British politics.That’s a powerful base for a recoveryit picks the right leader.The challenge is finding that person. As things stand, the field isn’t inspiring.Rebecca Long-Bailey — though a box-ticking superstar — doesn’t have the demonstrable competence that voters are yearning for from Labour.And poisonous Thornberry, who once tweeted a sneering comment about a Rochester home decorated with English flags, will repel patriotic voters.Butthe party is prepared to ditch the ersity nonsense and ignore pious pundits shrieking that the new leader “must be a woman”, the picture is rosier.The unbearably smug Keir Starmer — key player in the doomed People’s Vote campaign — would go down like a ton of bricks in Leave-voting areas.But someone like Dan Jarvis, who has called for Labour to make a “clean break” with the Corbyn era, may just have what it takes.Under Corbyn, Labour proved once and for all that wokeness doesn’t win elections.With the exception of naive students and hipster Londoners, voters don’t much care whether their politicians wear flat caps, headscarves or top hats. They just want politicians who are unafraid to act.So now MPs have a choice.Either they nominate duds with tear-jerking back- stories and shore up their majority in Putney — the right-on London seat which provided the only cause for celebration last time.Or they change tack, abandon wokery, and unearth a strong, competent leader, who might be up to the mammoth task of rebuilding the broken party.It really couldn’t be simpler.PO-FACED leftie commentators must stop laying in to journalists who call Boris “Boris” .They’ve been fighting a losing battle for years. And rightly so.Given Johnson is the third most common surname in the UK, it’s practical – not chummy – to call the Prime Minister by his much rarer Christian name.But, more importantly, the fact our PM is known by his first name on the world stage should be a source of pride to Brits.After three dreary years of Theresa May, Boris’s gravitas and quirky iniduality could hardly be more refreshing.It’s time to embrace it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: ex army chief blasts corbyn for backing our enemies
story: Colonel Richard Kemp accused the Labour boss of being a “mouthpiece” for the Iranian regime - after Mr Corbyn slammed “belligerent” Donald Trump for taking out general Qasem Soleimani at Baghdad Airport.He told SunOnline: “[Jeremy] Corbyn can always be relied on to back our enemies over our allies and that is why he sides with Iran over the US.“He was previously a paid mouthpiece of the same regime in Iran as Soleimani served by delivering acts of terrorism around the world.”Mr Corbyn has previously faced criticism for his relations with Iran after he appeared on the nation’s state TV for fees of up to £,.He was slammed in June last year as pathetic by then Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt after calling on the government to provide “credible evidence” that Tehran was behind attacks on British oil tankers.Col Kemp’s comments come after Mr Corbyn condemned President Trump for bringing Iran and the US to the brink of war, following threats of crushing revenge by Tehran.He tweeted: “The US assassination of Qasem Soleimani is an extremely serious and dangerous escalation of conflict with global signicance.“The UK government should urge restraint on the part of both Iran and the US, and stand up to the belligerent actions and rhetoric coming from the US.”It is believed the PM had no forewarning about the Soleimani strike from Mr Trump, despite signicant UK interests and , military personnel in Iraq and Syria.But U.S. secretary of state Mike Pompeo claimed he discussed the decision to take defensive action to eliminate Qassem Soleimani with Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab.Mr Pompeo added that he is thankful that our allies recognise the continuing aggressive threats posed by the Iranian Quds Force.Mr Johnson has been spending his Christmas break in sunnier climes - but could face calls toto Westminster after MPs blasted the drone strike as reckless.Col Kemp, a former COBRA chief and Britain’s commander in Aghanistan, has begged Boris to honour the Special Relationship and back Mr Trump over the attack.He told SunOnline: “The U.K. government should publicly back President Trump’s strike and also be ready to give the maximum possible military and diplomatic support to the US as the situation unfolds.“Soleimani ordered the killing of many British as well as American troops in Iraq and Afghanistan and it is right that he should have been made to pay the price for his murderous activities everywhere.”

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailChristmas trees should be replanted or recycled to help the fight against climate change, the Government says today. Tory ministers want families to dig their gardens this weekend and plant their redundant trees, rather than send them to the tip. If thereaposs no option to plant your trees, ministers also suggest checking whether councils have a special collection service - though that could prompt criticism, given the Tory cuts to councils in recent years. Or ministers suggest a recycling service that could use the trees to build flood barriers or turn them into path chippings or soil. The call is a boost for the Mirroraposs Million Trees campaign which aims to plant a million trees over five years. Today, just % of the UK is covered in trees, compared to the EU average of %. Globally,  billion more are cut down than are planted every year.  We have waged our fight with A Trillion Trees, a joint venture of the world’s largest conservation charities – WWF, BirdLe International and Wildle Conservation Society who are together fighting deforestation and to restore forests around the world. As Britons prepare to strip their festive trees before twelfth night and Epiphany on Monday, Environment Minister Rebecca Pow urged households to consider keeping their trees. She said: “Millions of families around the UK celebrated Christmas with a beautul fir or spruce tree in their home, but when the decorations are taken down it’s important that we dispose of trees sustainably. “If you have a tree with its roots still attached, then replanting your Christmas tree is a great way to reduce your carbon footprint and help our efforts to plant more trees.” According to the British Christmas Tree Growers Association, between six and eight million real Christmas trees are sold in the UK every year.If not reused or recycled, real trees can end up in landfill. Sending eight million trees to the local dump would cost about £million. A typical six to seven foot high Christmas tree is between  and  years old. Nordmann Firs are the most popular in British homes, making up % of those sold, with Norway Spruce making up  to %. According to the Committee on Climate Change, the Government’s statutory advisers on the climate crisis, the UK should have .billion new trees by  to meet its net zero carbon target. But last year just , hectares of its ,-hectare yearly target were planted. The Government said real Christmas trees which were not replanted can be shredded into chippings, which can be used in parks or woodland areas.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLabourapossLisa Nandy has become the fourth MP to launch her leadership bid - saying the party risks becoming irrelevantit doesnapost change. She follows colleagues Clive Lewis, Jess Phillips and Emily Thornberry in announcing she wants to succeed Jeremy Corbyn. Mr Corbyn is standing down following Labouraposs crushing defeat in last monthaposs general election, which saw its worst performance since . Writing in the Wigan Post, Ms Nandy said believes the party has to change to regain the trust of voters after suffering the huge loss. She said the drubbing at the hands of Boris Johnsonaposs Conservatives - which included losing swathes of seats in its northern heartlands - was a long time coming”. And she argues that the next leader should come from those areas which feel neglected and are turning away from the party, with a deep understanding of the problems the regions face. She said: It has been  years since Labour last won power, and I want you to know I have listened and I understand that we have one chance to win back the trust of people in Wigan, Workington and Wrexham. Without what were once our Labour heartlands we will never win power in Westminster and help to build the country we know we can be.  I know that a Labour Party led by someone like me is something many of you do not believe is possible. I think we can, and must, show that it is. “I have heard you loud and clear when you said to earn that trust means we need a leader who is proud to be from those communities, has skin in the game, and is prepare to go out, listen and bring Labour home to you. “I wanted to tell you first that I’m standing to be leader of the Labour Party because after a decade of having the privilege to represent you, I have a deeper understanding of what has gone awry in our discredited political system.  “I’m standing because I know too many people in places like Wigan no longer feel they have a voice in our national story. So many of you have told me you believe many leaders are not interested in what you have to say and are unable - or unwilling - to understand your lives. I believe you are right.” Ms Nandy, who served as the shadow energy secretary from  to , said she was heartbroken that so many working class constituencies had chosen the Conservatives over Labour at the last general election .  She criticises Westminster heavily in her leadership pitch, calling for devolution and decision-making abilities for “every town, city, region and nation in the UK”. She says she wanted communities to be able to create a dferent future for themselves, not rely on top-down initiatives from governments. She added: “Now is not the time to steady the ship or try not to oversteer. What is needed are the hard yards of winning the argument inch by inch in town halls, workplaces and pubs.

story: NewsHMV closures: Full list of stores shutting down after signs appear across UKNine HMV stores are closing around the UK by the end of January including in the major cities of Birmingham, Plymouth and Leeds, in bid to re-jig business portfolioShareCommentsByLila Randall:,  JAN NewsHMV has put closing down signs in nine of its UK stores" to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - daily newsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAt least eight HMV stores are to be axed from the UK high street after the music giant quietly begun shutting down the venues last month. Word of the latest closures was spread by members of the public who posted photos of store closure signs in shop windows on social media. However, in many cases HMV has not made any public announcements. The outlets affected are in Leeds, Reading, Plymouth, the Bullring in Birmingham, Worcester, Bury St Edmunds, Grimsby, and Nuneaton. Reading’s HMV store in The Oracle launched a closing down sale on January , and closing down posters were put up in the mall. However, it is unclear whether the store is closing down for good or whether it’s relocating. Plymouth’s Drake Circus HMV is making way for a fresh retailer, leaving the centre on January  and re-opening in the former Maplin store in nearby Cornwall Street, also in the heart of the city centre. One disappointed shopper wrote on Twitter : “My heart dropped when I saw the Closing sign, then realised they’re just moving, sad to see the store go by glad Plymouth will still have a HMV! #hmv” .Have you seen an HMV close down near you  Email webnews@mirror In Grimsby, the Freshney Place branch announced it will shut its doors later this month with for sale signs on almost all of its products and ‘store closing’ signs in its windows. However, HMV says it’s in talks with Freshney Place regarding the closures, and will inform customers “ anything changes”. A HMV spokesperson said: “At this time, talks are ongoing with the landlords involved and are currently progressing in a positive direction. “Thank you to the community for their ongoing support for us and we will let you knowanything changes.” Meanwhile, HMV in Worcester’s Crowngate Shopping Centre will close its doors on January  after the new business owner said the store was ‘no longer viable’.  A spokesman from HMV said: “Regretfully we can confirm that HMV Worcester will be closing, despite our desire to continue trading in this location.” HMV Nuneaton in the Ropewalk Shopping Centre will also close at the end of January after it was unable to agree a new deal with the landlord. Meanwhile, in Bury St Edmunds’ Arc Shopping Centre, the music will close its doors on January , and is rumoured to be making way for sports retailer JD Sports. HMV’s Birmingham store in the Bullring shopping centre is due to pull down its shutters at the end of January. Staff were told the opening of an HMV in the entertainment store at the fringe of the city centre, called HMV Vault, would eventually lead to the Bullring closure as its overheads are much higher. At the moment there isn’t a signicant sale at the store, though some prices have been discounted but many vinyl products have not. A statement issues by the Bullring shopping centre’s owner Hammerson said: “We can confirm that the HMV store at the Bullring is due to close. HMV recently opened Europeaposs largest entertainment store with Hammerson, HMV Vault, at Birmingham’s Dale End. Bury, which was also thought to be closing its store, announced on Twitter this morning that it would ‘stick around a lot longer’.  In December, HMV owner Doug Putman said Christmas was “crunch time” as the determiner of whether the handwork put into building the brand throughout the year pays off through festive sales. He told the BBC: ”All the hard work you do for  months of the year, that period is when you see it come to fruition and you see how good a job you did.

story: NewsThousands of monkeys being bred in misery across UK as home pet trade exposedEXCLUSIVE: Celebrity owners and a desire to stand out on social media are seeing an explosion in the trade in pet monkeys which is legal despite terrible psychological and physical suffering for the poor monkeysShareCommentsByNada FarhoudEnvironment editor:,  JAN NewsJoey" to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - daily newsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThousands of monkeys are being bred in homes across the UK in a squalid but legal suburban pet trade. Trapped indoors, some never leave their tiny cages and suffer devastating illnesses ranging from depression to brittle bones. Some are so badly neglected they need to be put down. Rescue workers say their popularity as pets is rising thanks to celebrity owners and a desire to stand out on social media. Tens of thousands of primates across Europe are in desperate need of rescue but are left to suffer as sanctuaries are now full. Rachel Hevesi, of Wild Futures monkey sanctuary in Looe, Cornwall, said: “The UK trade, which is still legal, leads to huge psychological and physical suffering. “Every time a celebrity is pictured holding a monkey we wonder what this will do to the demand. We have to turn away mon­­keys in desperate need as our sanctuary, and others, are full.” Breeding and selling small monkeys such as marmosets and tamarins is legal with a licence under the Dangerous Wild Animals Act. But welfare experts say as few as % are actually licensed. The exact number of primates kept as UK pets is unknown. In  it was estimated at up to , but given the inc­­reased popularity, it could now be higher. Capuchins are among the most popular. Two years ago they would fetch £, but they now sell online for just £ due to a surge in home breeding. Capuchin Joey was imported from South America with legal papers. But once in his UK home he had no access to direct sunlight, was alone for  hours a day and was unable to exercise.  He ended up with rickets and also rocked so obsessively he developed an open wound at the base of his spine. Primate expert Dr Ben Garrod, from the University of East Anglia, said: “Primates do not make good pets. Keeping them drives their extinction in the wild. “It’s hard enough for a zoo to keep a healthy population let alone someone who, even with the best intentions, simply doesn’t have the time, money or expertise.”  Dr Garrod said  European countries have some form of ban on pet primates and called for them to be made illegal here.He also called celebrities such as Justin Bieber , who share pictures with pet mon­­keys, “morons”. The RSPCA, which has urged action for years, said it received calls about monkeys most weeks.

title: veganuary best worst veggie versions
story: NewsVeganuary: The best and worst veggie versions of fast food classicsAfter Greggs released a no-steak vegan bake yesterday, we test the new arrivals in all things vegan fast food from KFC, McDonald’s, Costa, Subway, Pizza Hut and more to see which pass the meat-eater taste test...ShareCommentsByPoppy Danby:,  JAN NewsA selection of vegan fast foods " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - daily newsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAfter Greggs released a no-steak vegan bake, we check out the arrivals in vegan fast food from KFC, McDonald’s, Costa, Subway, Pizza Hut and more to see which pass the meateater taste test... Waitrose Asian inspired BBQ Mushrooms with Sticky Rice How much: £. What’s in it: Aromatic sticky rice is partnered with marinated and roasted portobello mushrooms, pak choi and pickled vegetables in a spicy chilli and garlic sauce. Taste verdict: I was so keen to try this dish that I burned my mouth in excitement. But it was definitely worth it. The tangy sauce and thick strands of mushroom partnered perfectly and were almost meaty in texture. In fact, there wasn’t mushroom for improvement. Rating:   I’d definitely miss out on meat to enjoy this meal again.  MS Beetroot and Carrot Bourguignon How much: £. What’s in it: MS have made their bourguignon with root vegetables to be served with a caullower mash. Taste verdict: One of new items available in the Plant Kitchen vegan range, the Beetroot and Carrot Bourguignon was filled with huge chunks of root veg and the ready meal was certainly filling. The creamy mash went down a treat too! However, there was a slightly sweet after-taste to the dish due to the beetroot sauce, which was a little off-putting. Rating:   Tasty enough but meat can’t be beat for this classic.  Pizza Hut Pepperphoni pizza How much: £. for a regular-sized pizza. What’s in it: Pea protein and Viole vegan cheese provide the perfect basis for this plant-based pizza. Taste verdict: Bubbling with “cheese” as I opened the box, this pizza looked like any peperoni fan’s dream. The taste was good but was overshadowed by the rubbery texture of the topping, which left it feeling a bit stodgy. If you fancy a pizza then I’d look where for a slice of the action. Rating:   Only real pepperoni can cut the crust when it comes to a Pizza Hut takeaway.  Subway Meatless Meatball Marinara How much: £. What’s in it: The new sub features the same delicious marinara sauce as the original. However, the plant-based alternative is stuffed with vegan cheese and plant-based meatballs. Taste verdict: The Meatball Marinara is one of Subway’s most iconic sandwiches, so it was a bold choice to create a plant-based alternative for Veganuary. However, this was just as good as the original. The meatless meatballs had a nice, authentic texture and the sauce was so good that my only criticism is that I would have liked more. Rating:  : Definitely not a sub standard attempt at a meat-free alternative.  Wagamama Vegan “tuna” How much: £. What’s in it: The strange sounding dish is made with dehydrated watermelon which is sliced, seared and served hot to give the texture of tuna sashimi. Taste verdict: This concoction tastes just as odd as it sounds. Surprisingly, on first appearances, the hot watermelon looked just like regular sushi but just one bite had me screwing up my face as my brain struggled to come to terms with what I was eating. And, at nearly £ a bowl, there’s definitely something a bit fishy about this idea. Rating:   I wouldn’t bother with this. Butyou still fancy going vegan then Wagamama’s have a range of other dishes, such as a Yasai Katsu Curry or Kare Burosu Ramen, which are plant-based without being too peculiar.  KFC Vegan Burger How much: £. What’s in it: Casting their signature chicken aside, KFC use an Original Recipe Quorn fillet for their vegan burger. This is then coated in the restaurant’s special  herbs and spices and served in a sesame bun with fresh lettuce and vegan mayo. Taste verdict: As a big fan of The Colonel’s chicken I was a little sceptical about whether KFC could work in vegan form. But the Quorn fillet was seasoned perfectly and aside from a slightly chewy texture was more than a bit moreish. Rating:   A finger lickin’ good opportunity to replace meat this Veganuary.  Costa Vegan Smokey Ham  CheeZe Toastie How much: £. What’s in it: The coffee chain boasts that it’s plant-based snack is made with Quorn smokey ham and coconut cheese sandwiched between two slices of vegan bread. Taste verdict: This was a simple offering from Costa as part of their new vegan range. Unfortunately, there wasn’t much filling, so the toastie was a little thin and the Quorn was hard to taste. But the vegan cheese was soft, melty and hard to distinguish from any other piece of cheddar. Rating:   If Costa added a little more filling then the original cheese and ham toastie would be... well... toast.McDonaldaposs Veggie Dippers How much: £. What’s in it: Both vegan compliant and gluten free, McDonalds’ Veggie Dippers are made with red pepper, rice, sundried tomato pesto and split peas. They’re also coated with light and crispy breadcrumbs.

Emily Elliott, , of Huddersfield, attempted to take her own le just weeks after she split from partner Shay Doyle, who she met at Huddersfield University. She recovered and they rekindled their relationship, but a few months later Emily was found dead at home. Mr Doyle discovered her body on June , several months after they had initially broken up because Mr Doyle had been contacting another girl through Facebook , Bradford Coroneraposs Court heard. The two former University of Huddesrfield students had a turbulent relationship, assistant coroner John Broadbridge heard. Mr Doyle, of Wilmslow, Cheshire, gave evidence in front of Miss Elliottaposs family including her father Stan and mother Zarah Khilji as well as her brothers Fox and Jacob. He explained they had met initially as friends at university around  . Miss Elliott, a former Greenhead College student, had studied Sociology but failed her course after the first year while Mr Doyle studied a Graphics Design course. The court heard she was a very attractive, sociable young woman who had lots of friends and worked in bars and clubs such as The Warehouse, Camel Club and Mavericks. She had also worked previously at Tesco in Marsh. Mr Doyle was questioned by Mr Broadbridge about how their relationship began. He said: After eight-to-nine months there was flirting and getting a bit closer to one another. She lived with me and three of my friends in Huddersfield for a while, a couple of months. I would say we had a good relationship though we had the odd argument like any other couple. We split up. I had been texting another girl through Facebook. The coroner asked him: Can you accept that Emily was extremely distressed when she found out about this relationship and, to say the least, reacted badly  Mr Doyle agreed that was so. He was then questioned about Miss Elliottaposs attempt to take her own le in February . Mr Broadbridge asked: How soon did that occur after your separation  Mr Doyle, who admitted he was not good with dates replied: A friend told me. A month or two after it happened. Mr Broadbridge told him the attempt took place on February  and said: So it would not be a month, it would be a matter of weeks or days  Mr Doyle said: I found out a month or so after it happened. He said they had blocked one another on social media in the aftermath of his cheating but at the end of March had rekindled their relationship, though by now he was living in Wilmslow. Mr Doyle said: Things were going well, we talked about having children together.  But the court heard that on Thursday,  June, Mr Doyle got no response when he tried calling her so he sent a text message to one of her best friends, Kimberley Knight, askingshe had heard anything to which she replied that she had had some weird messages from her. Mr Doyle caught a train to Huddersfield Rail Station and then a cab to her home which she shared with her father. He broke down in tears as he told how he found the front door open. He said: I went upstairs and Emilyaposs bedroom door was closed. He opened the door and found her unresponsive. He said he screamed for help, dialled  and attempted to perform CPR before paramedics took over. The coroner asked him: Was there any clue in those few days that she was desperate, that she might harm herself  Mr Doyle replied: No. The coroner said: Were you shocked at what you saw  Mr Doyle: Yes. After hearing a wealth of evidence about Miss Elliottaposs history of mental health problems, previous overdose attempts and heavy drinking the coroner concluded that she had taken her own le.

Josias Fletchman, , from Manchester, was on holiday at the Costa del Sol resort when three family members lost their lives. Gabriel Diya, , his daughter Comfort, nine, and his son Praise-Emmanuel, , drowned at the Club La Costa World in Spain on Christmas Eve. Mr Fletchman knew something was seriously wrong when a Spanish woman ran into a hotel lobby making a “death cry”. He was one of the first people at the scene and gave CPR to Praise-Emmanuel at the poolside. The youth support worker has said the deaths could have been preventedthere was a leguard manning the pool at all times andstaff had walkie talkies to alert colleagues at the hotel, rather than running to noty reception. Three cleaners who could not swim were the first to arrive at the scene and they had to wait several minutes to get help. Mr Fletchman said: Iaposm not going to sit here and blame anybody, but...it was my family that it happened to... Iaposd be raising alarm bells.”  He added, My Diya “wouldn’t have had to jump in” to try and rescue his childrenthere was a leguard. Mother and we Olubunmi Diya previously claimed her familyaposs deaths were caused by a fault with the pool. A police spokesman described the tragedy as a freak accident and put it down to a lack of swimming ability. The resortaposs operator, CLC World Resorts and Hotels, said the police investigation confirmed the pool was working normally and there was no mal of any kind.  In an initial statement, the resort’s operator CLC World Resorts and Hotels said hotel staff found the three guests unresponsive in the pool, prompting first response teams and emergency services to administer first aid. On December , the resort published its condolences to the family, saying it was “devastated” by the tragedy. It added: “The Guardia Civil have carried out a full investigation which found no concerns relating to the pool in question or procedures in place, which leaves us to believe this was a tragic accident which has left everyone surrounding the incident in shock. “Naturally our primary concern remains the care and support of the remaining family members. Mrs Diyaaposs -year-old daughter, Favour, was also in the pool at the time of the tragedy and had become scared after realising the deep-end was located in the centre of the pool. Favour said she managed to get out of the water and threw a le buoy into the pool when her brother screamed for help.  In a statement to Spanish police, she said: “We never thought the deepest part of the pool was in the middle and the slope in the pool made her [Comfort] slide towards the middle and that was the reason my sister was there and the reason why I ended up slipping towards that area.” “I realised I was out of my depth soon after I got into the water. “I got scared and only managed to get out of the water with some effort because I’m not used to swimming in places where the water is deep and I can’t stand up. A police source said investigators were informed the three relatives didnapost know how to swim or didnapost swim very well. The source also discredited speculation about the pool pump system that could have made it hard for the group to swim, noting that investigators found no evidence pointing to any anomalies like increased suction pressure.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMariam Nabatanzi was just  when she was married to a man almost four times her age. By the time she was , she had her first set of twins and following that quads, triplets and twins just kept coming. Mariam suffers from a rare genetic condition and by the time she was  she had given birth to  children. She was also left to raise her massive brood alone when her husband walked out on her four years ago. The devoted mum has three sets of quadruplets, four sets of triplets and six sets of twins. She works tirelessly to make sure she feeds her youngsters and keeps a roof over their head. Mariam works as a hairdresser, an event decorator and collects and sells scrap metal. She also brews her own local gin to sell and makes herbal medicine. Mariam is determined her children will have all the chances in le that she was denied. Most of her wages are spent on food, medical care, clothes and school fees.  Photos of her older children graduating from school hang proudly on the walls of her home. But despite Mariamaposs best efforts, one of her children, Ivan Kibuka, had to drop out of school to help raise the family. The -year-old said: Mum is overwhelmed, the work is crushing her, we help where we can, like in cooking and washing, but she still carries the whole burden for the family. I feel for her. Mariam and her children live in tough conditions in just four tiny homes in Uganda. The buildings are made from cement bricks and a corrugated iron roof and they are surrounded by coffee fields.  Mariamaposs own childhood was filled with heartbreak and tragedy. Just three days after she was born, Mariamaposs mum walked out on her, her father and her five siblings. Her father re-married but her step-mother poisoned Mariamaposs older siblings by mixing cut glass in their food. Mariam was the only one to survive because she was visiting a relative. She said: I was seven years old then, too young to even understand what death actually meant.  I was told by relatives what had happened. Losing her siblings at such a young age meant Mariam was desperate for a family of her own. She only ever wanted six children but her rare genetic condition meant she had unusually large oies. She was warned by a doctor that any birth control, like the contraceptive Pill, would cause her problems. After her first set of twins, Mariamaposs babies just kept coming.  Large families are the norm in Uganda, with women having . children on average, but Mariamaposs family is gigantic even by these standards. When she was , and having given birth to  children, Mariam begged her doctor to stop her having any more babies. But once again he was told that the best thing for her to do would be to keep getting pregnant because her oy count was so high. Almost four years ago Mariam fell pregnant for the final time - and it ended in tragedy. While she was in labour one of her twins died.  Then her husband, who would often be absent from the family home for long periods, abandoned her and his children for good. His name is now cursed in Mariamaposs family. She said: I have grown up in tears, my man has passed me through a lot of suffering. All my time has been spent looking after my children and working to earn some money. But her last baby also meant Mariam finally got the help she needed to stop having more children.  Dr Charles Kiggundu, a gynecologist at Mulago Hospital in Kampala, Uganda, said: Her case is genetic predisposition to hyper-ovulate, which is releasing multiple eggs in one cycle, which signicantly increases the chance of having multiples it is always genetic. Mariam says medics took action to stop her becoming pregnant again. She added that her doctor told her he had cut my uterus from inside. Mariam and her massive brood share the four, tiny, homes where the walls are caked with dirt and grime. She has metal bunk beds that  of her children sleep in but the others have to share either mattresses on the floor or sleep in the dirt because there simply isnapost the space.  And no matter how young, all the children have to help out with the chores. The family gets through kgs of maize flour every day to mke sure they have enough to eat - but meat and fish are rare treats. Mariam also has a rota of cooking and washing duties, proudly on display on a wooden board in the home.

title: cammy its time dee realise how good they can be
story: Cammy Kerr says it’s time the Dundee squad realised how good they can be as they embark on what they plan is a positive .The Dark Blues ended  on a positive note after a strong showing in a - draw at rivals Dundee United followed up back-to-back wins against Dunfermline and Partick.After a calendar year to forget at Dens Park, Kerr plans to use their recent good run to hit the ground running for the second half of the campaign, starting tomorrow at home to Inverness.He told the Tele: “ wasn’t a good year.“Even as a young boy coming through when my first season full-time was the ‘Club ’ season. That was a dficult time.“We’ve had loads of ups and downs but the past year is certainly one, for the first half of it anyway, we want to put behind us as quickly as possible.“With the recent bit of form and positivity, we take that into  and kick on.”Dundee start the year with three home matches on the bounce, firstly against potential play-off rivals Caley Thistle and Ayr United before they welcome high-flying Premiership side Motherwell to Dens Park for a Scottish Cup tie.“We have dficult games coming up. We have three games at home now and we need to get back to making this place a fortress,” Kerr added.“I said it at the start of the season that,we wanted to do anything in this league, we’ve got to make our home form much better than it has been.“It is better than it has been over the past year but it’s still not where we want it to be.“That’s something we are working so hard every day to put right.“Every game we go into, we expect ourselves to win. That’s not being arrogant or cocky but what Dundee should be aiming for.“There needs to be a realisation of how good this squad can be.”And Kerr says the second half against league leaders United last Friday gives everyone associated with the club belief they can start looking upwards.“There was a wee realisation after the game we could have taken three points.“The boys have spoken since and we’re starting to realise how well we can do as a team.“After we got the goal at Tannadice, there was a belief on the pitch and I think the fans felt that.“Even when the board went up for how long was left, the fans still thought we could win it.“Hopefully, that is a wee turning point for us – it needs to be going forward.“There has been a lot of disappointment, a lot of games where we have huffed and puffed throughout the season.“Last Friday, the fans came again in their numbers and I didn’t expect there to be so many, to be honest.“United had three of the stands but our fans were so loud again and when we scored it was great to go and celebrate with them.“Our fans have had to endure a dficult year, especially with United being on top since day one.“We are happy with how it went but, at the same time, we need to make sure we don’t rest on a draw – we need to remember we didn’t win – but use it to kick us on.”Dundee have faced the Caley Jags three times this season, winning -, drawing - and losing - last time in Inverness.Dundee United - Dundee: Dorrans# first goal earns Dee derby point" src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp dundee-united---dundee-dorrans-first-goal-earns-dee-derby-point embed # secretynOUlpvmC" data-secret"ynOUlpvmC" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"Kerr added: “We are under no illusions how tough it will be tomorrow. Inverness are second for a reason.“They beat us last time. I was on the bench that day but the boys won’t mind me saying we didn’t do ourselves justice.“We huffed and puffed, had loads of possession but we weren’t good enough on the day to be the team everyone wants us to be – we need to make up for that.”

title: dee utd team of the decade the best of 2010s
story: Greg Stewart or Johnny Russell  Gary Mackay-Steven or Gary Harkins  Darren O’Dea or Sean Dillon Who is the best we’ve seen in the City of Discovery over the past  years As we head into the s, Tele Sport writers George Cran and Calum Woodger looked back over the decade and, after a debate on the Twa Teams, One Street podcast, brought together the EveningTeam of the Decade.Goalkeeper: Scott BainArriving at Dens Park a year before the club won the Championship, Bain made himself club No  in the Premiership.After  appearances for the club, Bain left for Celtic and has played three times for Scotland.Defence: Gary IrvineA favourite among Dundee fans who crowned Irvine ‘the White Cafu’ after a flurry of goals from right-back, the defender made almost  appearances for the club.Defenders: Sean DillonA modern day club legend, ‘Dillo’ spent more than  years at Dundee United, winning the Scottish Cup in .He went on to captain the club for four seasons in the top-flight before departing in  after making  appearances in tangerine.James McPakeDillon and McPake shook hands six times as captains in Dundee derbies, with the United man getting the better of the results.McPake, though, is remembered as a player for two derby goals – one in a - win for his side and the second a late leveller at Tannadice.He may only have made  appearances for the club before injury ended his career early but McPake’s leadership on the pitch earns him a place in this team.Andrew RobertsonVery little has to be said about this choice – Robertson was a star in the making at Tannadice.Arriving as an unknown -year-old from Queen’s Park, Robertson swtly made the left-back place his own and became well-known for rampaging runs down the flank.Just a year later, he was off to Hull City for £. million and has since become a European Cup winner with Liverpool and Scotland captain.His  games for United brought five goals.Midfielders:Gary Mackay-StevenThe wing wizard edged out Dundee favourite Gary Harkins for the right-wing berth in our team.‘GMS’ was an entertainer with an array of tricks and flicks and was a major part of the free-flowing football that made the Tangerines a regular top-six outfit under Jackie McNamara.Stuart ArmstrongArmstrong and ‘GMS’ were inseparable at the top end of Scottish football for years before the former moved down south to Southampton.Armstrong’s athleticism and ability on the ball made him the focal point of United’s attack during six years at the club from  to .Kevin ThomsonHe may only have played  times for the Dens Park club.However, Thomson’s ability and nous in the middle of the park played a huge role in Dundee’s top-six finish in -.Craig ConwayA man scoring two goals in a Scottish Cup Final win is a must for a team like this.A compact, tricky attacker, Conway went on to enjoy a fine career for himself down south after making his name at Tannadice.Strikers: Greg StewartPlucked from Cowdenbeath, Stewart was arguably Dundee’s Player of the Decade.Shortlisted for the - PFA Scotland Players’ Player of the Year award, Stewart terrorised Premiership defences in dark blue.Twenty-two league goals in  top-flight matches from his time at the club is a sizeablewith his trademark curled finishes a regular sight at Dens Park.Jon DalyAnother Scottish Cup winner in his time in the city, Daly was a colossus for Dundee United.A real targetman, Daly was key in the early part of the decade with - a bumper year with  league goals in the top flight after winning the Scottish Cup in .The Irishman managed  goals in just over  games for the club –  of those goals came after .Manager: Peter HoustonShortly after taking over from Craig Levein, Houston led the Tangerines to a famous Scottish Cup triumph in  – only the second United manager to ever lt the trophy.Have your say on Tele Sport’s choices by emailing sport@eveningtelegraph

title: dundee frustrated but draw shows why utd are so far clear at top
story: I can see James McPake’s frustration that Dundee didn’t win on Friday night but the - draw at Tannadice showed exactly why Dundee United are where they are.The Dark Blues probably were the better team in the end and they’ll take plenty of positives out of it but it was a good result for the Tangerines, too.I agree with manager Robbie Neilson saying his side didn’t play as well as they could have.For some reason, they looked a bit anxious and nervy in the second half which is completely unlike them.United had done so well in the previous derbies and been so assured it was a surprise to see them just lump the ball forward as the game wore on.However, the sign of a title-winning team is they can still take a point despite not playing well against one of the better sides in the ision.And they even extended their lead at the top as, once more, the other sides failed to take advantage of United dropping points.For James and his side, they were far better than previous derby showings, that much is obvious.It was a step forward for them and will give their fans a positive jolt heading into the new year.I still think they have problems creating chances.They had lots of good play in the second half but still can’t convert that into clear-cut opportunities.Look at the stats and, though Dundee about edged the game for me, United still had more shots on goal.I do think the way the Dens gaffer has set up his team recently suits them better and that showed on Friday night.There’s more balance in the midfield with Fin Robertson and Graham Dorrans taking turns to control things in the middle.It’s taken a while, which is understandable given the big changes in the summer, but James is starting to find a good formation and his best starting XI.These things always take time but it seems like the Dee are getting there.The key is they kick on from here.For United, it’s about ticking over and keeping themselves well clear of any trouble at the top.Sounds like there were a fair few interested parties at the derby, no doubt taking a look at Lawrence Shankland after his goalscoring exploits this season.It wouldn’t surprise methose English clubs were keeping an eye on Robertson and Dorrans either, the way those two are performing.
